posts._title: Koji Wakamatsu – 17-sai no fukei – shonen wa nani o mita no ka AKA Cycling Chronicles: Landscapes the Boy saw (2004)
posts.title: 17-sai no fukei – shonen wa nani o mita no ka
posts.excerpt: Kôji Wakamatsu’s Cycling Chronicles: Landscapes the Boy Saw (17-sai no fûkei – shônen wa nani o mita no ka) – a.k.a. “Cycle Chronicles – Landscapes the Boy Saw” and “17 and Life” – is scheduled to have its U.S. première at the 49th San Francisco International Film Festival (SFIFF) on April 27th at 8:45 p.m., …
posts.titleEnglish: Cycling Chronicles: Landscapes the Boy saw

posts._title: Leo Hurwitz – Dialogue with a Woman Departed (1980)
posts.title: Dialogue with a Woman Departed
posts.excerpt: The late filmmaker Leo Hurwitz created this documentary tribute to his deceased wife Peggy Lawson by mixing both actual footage of historical events, clips from his own films, and personal remembrances of her life. Lawson was a partner in Hurwitz’s cinematic endeavors and shared his commitment to political and social change. Hurwitz brings up images …

posts.title: The Thief
posts.excerpt: Review: A telephone rings in the dark—three times, pauses, then rings three times again. A fully-clothed figure lights a cigarette before rising from bed, dons a raincoat, then sets out into the night. Another figure emerges from the shadows, lights a cigarette, then discards a crumpled cigarette pack, which the first picks up and carries …

posts._title: Claude Chabrol – Les fantômes du chapelier AKA The Hatter’s Ghost (1982)
posts.title: Les fantômes du chapelier
posts.excerpt: synopsis In this murder mystery, a homicidal maniac goes on a killing spree beginning with his wife. He then kills six of her friends and is preparing to murder a seventh when the intended victim dies naturally. As a substitute, he murders his favorite hooker, leading the police right to him.

posts._title: Yasuzo Masumura – Ongaku aka The Music (1972)
posts.title: Ongaku
posts.excerpt: Masumura has been one of the most intersting directors for many of us Japanese cinema buffs. His “Blind Beasts” is a real classic and a disturbing film, almost an archetype of movies dealing with dark sexual passions, abductions and growing affection to an abuser. Masumura’s much less known film “The Music” also deals with dark …

posts._title: Philippe Garrel – Le Bleu des origines (1979)
posts.title: Le Bleu des origines
posts.excerpt: Extremly beautiful avant-garde film by Philippe Garrel, one of his silent ones. Nico, Zouzou and (almost a cameo) Jean Seberg are portraited by the camera with mistical intimacy. Is the last of the seventh garrel’s films with nico, and the last aparition of Seberg on a screen before her death.

posts.title: Berceau de cristal
posts.excerpt: funny imdb comment: Quote: A weird and dreamy minimalist underground art movie, Le Berceau de Cristal offers no joy whatsoever to mainstream film buffs – but doomed romantics, drug takers and fans of director Philippe Garrel may find it hypnotic and profoundly moving. posts.title: Die Freunde der Freunde
posts.excerpt: stefflbw wrote: Synopsis: Set in the boarding school milieu, the film depicts the meeting of shy Gregor and mysterious Billie. Billie has a son, her husband is in jail. posts._title: Byambasuren Davaa – Die Höhle des gelben Hundes AKA The Cave of the Yellow Dog [+Extras] (2005)
posts.title: Die Höhle des gelben Hundes
posts.excerpt: Movie Plot: The little nomad girl Nansal finds a baby dog in the mongolian veld, who becomes her best friend – against all rejections of her parents.
